author: sfgate.com
title: Microsoft rolls out tablets, phones to push Windows 10 ecosystem
text:
In a relatively new strategy for the company, Microsoft is using its own hardware to lure people to its software.
On Tuesday, it introduced its latest tablets, phones and fitness trackers because those consumer electronics products are more crucial than ever for the success of the company’s core Windows 10 software.
“Microsoft is trying to drive people to their service offerings,” analyst Patrick Moorhead said after attending Microsoft’s Windows 10 Devices event in New York.
“Windows as a service, that’s really what these devices are all about,” said Moorhead, president of Moor Insights & Strategy. “Companies like Apple and Google are stealing the limelight, so this was especially important for them.”
Microsoft hopes to tie its beefed-up consumer-device lineup into momentum from its new cloud-centric software-as-a-service offerings, including Office 2016 , released last month.
Microsoft reported Windows 10 , released in July, now runs on 110 million devices. CEO Satya Nadella said the company wants to “move people from needing Windows to choosing Windows to loving Windows.”
Microsoft introduced two new Surface tablets. The first company-designed PC sold poorly when introduced in 2012, but the latest models show the company is now moving from a “position of strength,” Moorhead said in an interview.
In July, Microsoft reported Surface sales, driven by the Surface 3 and Surface Pro 3, generated $888 million in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, up 117 percent during the year. Tablets generated $3.6 billion in revenue, up 65 percent from the year before.
“One of the biggest reasons they’ve gotten into these devices is because their Windows franchise, with the success of Apple, was at risk,” he said.
On Tuesday, Microsoft introduced the Surface Book, a laptop with a tablet-style detachable screen. The Book starts $1,499, while the new Surface Pro 4 tablet will start at $899.
Analyst Geoff Blaber, vice president of research for CCS Insight, said via e-mail that the Book was “a highly innovative flagship device that will act as a much needed halo product for Windows 10 and the broader PC market. Surface Book proves that innovation in personal computing is not just confined to Apple’s Cupertino campus.”
But Blaber said Microsoft’s three new mobile phones, the Lumia 950, Lumia 950 XL and Lumia 550, still can’t challenge Apple, Google and Samsung.
“These new Lumia devices tick all the boxes in terms of specifications and features, but they are unlikely to be enough to lure customers away from the iPhone or Android-powered rivals,” he said.
Microsoft also introduced an upgraded Band 2 wearable device, with a curved screen, barometer and apps for messaging and fitness tracking. A Microsoft video on the Band 2 ended with a wing-suited BASE jumper.
Blaber called the Band 2 a “dramatic improvement” over the original’s “unattractive and uncomfortable design.”
Still, he said, “at $249, Microsoft is hoping to address the space between low-cost fitness bands and smartwatches, but it’s a segment that is yet to establish itself. And it’s a hefty price tag.”
Microsoft also touted an upcoming Windows 10 update to its Xbox One game console, and said a $3,000 development edition of its experimental HoloLens “mixed reality” headsets will start shipping in early 2016.
Analyst Daniel Ives of FBR Capital Markets said Microsoft still has to change its perception “as a ‘rounding error’ in the smartphone and tablet landscape. While the new hardware products look impressive, it all comes down to consumer adoption as Microsoft aggressively tries to change its image.”
Benny Evangelista is a San Francisco Chronicle staff writer. E-mail: bevangelista@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @ChronicleBenny
